header.title: Egyptian Love Spells and Rituals
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Egyptian Magic, Wicca, Love Spells, Rituals

central_thesis: This book provides a practical guide for applying Wiccan principles within an Ancient Egyptian magical framework, focusing on love, relationships, and emotional well-being. It emphasizes personal intent, positive energy, and adaptable practices for modern solitary practitioners or couples, drawing on the wisdom and pantheon of Ancient Egypt.

structure_content.summary: The author dedicates the work to Egyptian gods and goddesses (Amun, Hathor, Imhotep, Isis, Nephthys, Osiris, Ra, Thoth) as primary sources of inspiration for love, magic, and success, also thanking several individuals for their support.

Introduces the book as a guide to love and Egyptian magick, highlighting the Ancient Egyptian understanding of eternal love. It incorporates Wiccan principles and offers adaptable spells and rituals, often drawing from the female perspective but noting male adaptability. The myth of Osiris and Isis is presented as an example of eternal love and integrity.

Details the author's personal journey to Egyptian magick, from a Catholic upbringing to Wicca, emphasizing the search for a personal spiritual connection. It highlights Egyptian magick's spontaneous and less restrictive nature, requiring dedication and an open mind, and explains connection through meditation and personal spells.

structure_content.chapter_title: Magick in the Time of the Pharaohs
structure_content.summary: Explores Ancient Egyptian spiritual life, including deity worship, fertility rituals tied to the Nile, and how these practices are adapted for modern needs. It discusses the evolving nature of Egyptian gods, their roles in daily life, and contrasts the Cairo Calendar with the Wiccan Wheel of the Year. It also addresses ancient Egyptian kinship terminology ('brother'/'sister' as terms of endearment).

contextualizes modern Wiccan practice, debunking myths (e.g., no devil worship, no animal sacrifice). It stresses personal choice, the ethical framework of 'An it harm none, do as thou wilt' and the 'Law of Return,' and the transformative power of the mind through meditation and visualization in practical magic. It also covers divination methods and daily devotions.

This section explains how various factors  like candle color, moon phase, day of the week, crystals, oils, herbs, and incense  are aligned to enhance the energy and effectiveness of spells. It details elemental correspondences (Earth, Air, Fire, Water) linked to the Four Sons of Horus, emphasizing personalization in practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Crystals, Oils, Herbs and Incense in Egyptian Love Magick
structure_content.summary: Explores the use of crystals, essential oils, herbs, and incense in Egyptian love magic, highlighting their energy-boosting and symbolic properties. It provides extensive lists of oils for attracting love, lust, happiness, and for mourning, along with incense recipes, stressing personal experimentation and proper storage.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Essence of Egyptian Love Spells
structure_content.summary: Defines spells as targeted expressions of desire, varying in complexity based on need. It underscores the importance of intent and visualization, detailing candle spell mechanics, basic altar setups without casting a circle, and the ethical considerations for binding and banishing spells, emphasizing positive intentions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Egyptian Spells to Bring Love into Your Life
structure_content.summary: Presents a collection of practical spells for attracting new love or deepening existing attractions. These range from simple dandelion spells to more elaborate candle rituals involving specific oils, incantations, and visualizations, with guidance on timing (Waxing Moon, Full Moon) and deity invocation (Amun, Bast, Hathor, Imhotep, Isis, Osiris).

structure_content.chapter_title: Egyptian Spells to Celebrate and Deepen Love
structure_content.summary: Offers spells and activities designed to nurture and re-ignite passion in existing relationships. These involve sensual rituals with specific oils (Aflame With Desire, Glow Like Honey, Love No Other, My Sister's Loveliness, Quench Your Desire, Remain With Me Forever), music, and intimate interactions, emphasizing communication, trust, and mutual enjoyment.

Provides spells for resolving disagreements and healing relationships. It stresses honest communication, mutual understanding, and avoiding past grievances. Rituals use specific oils (Amber, Primrose, Cinnamon, Lavender, Violet) and incenses to foster peace, trust, and intimacy, with options for both partners to participate.

Addresses the emotional healing process after a relationship ends or a loved one is lost. It offers spells for releasing past bonds (Freedom From a Lover, Parting Lovers', Release From Love, When Love Ends, Banishing and Release) and emphasizes positive intentions for moving forward, including the concept of Handparting.

Details a comprehensive Handfasting ceremony, a Pagan marriage ritual, adaptable for general or private use. It includes preparations for creating a nemyss (head covering), mixing specific oils, powders, and incense (Joining of Souls, Passion powder), and a structured ritual sequence involving invocations, symbolic acts, and a culminating sacred sexual act.

Explores the Ancient Egyptian concept of rebirth and the afterlife, differing from Western reincarnation. It offers prayers and incantations for the terminally ill, at the moment of death, for deceased children, parents, and partners, aimed at providing solace, expressing grief, and finding guidance from deities (Ma'at, Anubis, Isis, Osiris, Nephthys, Set, Amun, Amenti).

Provides definitions for key terms used throughout the book, including magical practices (Anoint, Banishing spell, Binding spell, Incantation, Invoke, Magick, Poppet, Ritual, Spell, Scrying, Smudge), Wiccan concepts (Coven, Craft, Elements, Esbat, Handfasting, Handparting, Magickal name, Pagan, Sabbats, Wicca, Witchcraft), and Egyptian elements (Canopic jars, Correspondences).
Lists a diverse collection of books on Ancient Egypt, Wicca, witchcraft, aromatherapy, and related occult topics, encouraging further reading to deepen the practitioner's knowledge and skill.

key_concepts.definition: A spontaneous, uplifting, vital, passionate, and less restrictive form of witchcraft centered on Ancient Egyptian deities and their rich history. It emphasizes personal connection, intuition, and adaptation to modern life rather than strict dogmatic adherence.

The core drivers of all magical work, determining a spell's effectiveness and outcome. The author stresses clarity of desire, focused visualization, and genuine emotional investment as essential for manifestation.

A system of aligning various symbolic elements (e.g., candle colors, moon phases, days of the week, crystals, essential oils, herbs, incense) with specific magical intentions to amplify and direct the energy of a spell or ritual. This includes linking elements to the Four Sons of Horus.

The collection of gods and goddesses (e.g., Amun, Hathor, Isis, Osiris, Thoth, Bast, Set) invoked for their specific attributes and assistance in various aspects of life, including love, protection, healing, and guidance. The book outlines their roles, sacred animals, colors, and gemstones.

A primary operative method involving charging an unlit candle with intent, anointing it with oils, inscribing names or symbols, and often rolling it in herbs or glitter. The burning of the candle, often accompanied by incantations and visualization, releases the spell's energy. Candles are only blown out to 'blow away the intent' or 'release' a spell.

Magical operations aimed at 'tying' a person to another or stopping someone/something from causing harm. The author emphasizes approaching these spells with positive intentions, caution, and consideration for free will, warning against self-destructive obsession.

Rituals or spells designed to rid oneself of negative habits, influences, or persons. While Ancient Egyptians used them destructively, the author advocates for their use with positive intent, such as overcoming bad habits or dispelling negative effects on one's life, rather than harming others.

A Pagan marriage ritual for joining two persons, which can be performed for a specific period (e.g., a year and a day) or for life. It is presented as a commitment and celebration of love and devotion, adaptable to modern relationships.

key_concepts.term: An It Harm None, Do As Thou Wilt
key_concepts.definition: A foundational ethical tenet of Wicca, guiding practitioners to ensure their magical actions do not cause harm to others. This principle applies to all spells and rituals, particularly those concerning love and interpersonal relationships.

Another core Wiccan tenet stating that whatever energy (positive or negative) a practitioner sends out through magic will return to them, often threefold. This reinforces the importance of positive intent in all magical workings.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined by Dillaire is a hybrid of Wiccan ethical principles and Ancient Egyptian magical techniques, specifically tailored for love and relationship issues. It emphasizes the practitioner's 'intent' and 'will' as the primary drivers of magic, augmented by 'correspondences'  a layered system of aligning specific deities, elements, candle colors, moon phases, days of the week, crystals, oils, herbs, and incense. Rituals are structured but adaptable, focusing on personal expression and connection with the Egyptian Pantheon. The system differentiates between 'spells' (short, focused on specific needs) and 'rituals' (more formal, for celebration, dedication, or complex intentions). A key operative aspect is 'anointing' candles and other items with specially blended oils, often followed by incantations, visualization, and sometimes the burning of inscribed papers or poppets. The system incorporates both constructive magic (attraction, deepening love, reconciliation) and banishing magic (ending relationships, breaking habits), always within the 'An it harm none' and 'Law of Return' framework.

relevant_quotes.text: This book is for anyone interested in love and Egyptian magick. The Ancient Egyptians knew as well as we do that love is a driving force in life, and I have attempted to cover as many aspects of love and desire as possible, including the loss of a loved one.

But Egyptian magick is spontaneous, uplifting, vital, passionate and exciting, and less restrictive than other witchcraft traditions. It does not require special knowledge, study or progression through levels in order to become a priest or priestess, as do some traditions; it does require dedication, imagination and an open mind and heart.
All Wiccan traditions are based on two basic tenets: 'An it harm none, do as thou wilt' and the Law of Return - 'Whatever you send out, comes back threefold'.

The guidelines for each spell and ritual are just that - guidelines. These spells are to be personal expressions of your intent and devotion to the gods and goddesses. Feel free to experiment and substitute other oils, herbs or incenses if they mean more to you.

The Moon exerts an energy over all of us: cats and dogs howl at the Moon, hospitals and the police notice more activity around the Full Moon and the tides rise and fall due to its influence. I have always been drawn to the Moon - I can sit for hours, looking up at the stars and the Moon, feeling so connected with my deities and nature.

critical_analysis.relevance: Dillaire's work offers a distinct approach within modern occultism by integrating Wiccan ethical frameworks with the rich pantheon and magical practices of Ancient Egypt, specifically for love-related workings. This blending provides a fresh perspective for practitioners who resonate with Egyptian deities but also seek the adaptability and 'harm none' ethos of Wicca. The detailed correspondences (oils, herbs, colors, moon phases, days, elements linked to Four Sons of Horus) provide a comprehensive system that is both technically precise and flexible. Its focus on personal intent and emotional engagement makes it relevant for individuals seeking to actively shape their romantic and emotional lives through magic, while also addressing healing from loss, a less common but crucial aspect of love magic manuals. The inclusion of personal anecdotes lends authenticity and relatability to the instructions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book is primarily aimed at solitary Wiccan practitioners and those new to occultism or Egyptian magic, providing a structured yet adaptable system. It also appeals to individuals who are specifically drawn to Ancient Egyptian mythology and wish to incorporate its deities and symbology into their magical practices. The content is suitable for those seeking guidance in attracting new love, deepening existing relationships, resolving conflicts, or healing from heartbreak and loss. The emphasis on ethical considerations and personal intuition also makes it appropriate for practitioners who prioritize responsible and self-aware magical engagement. Its explicit instructions for both simple and elaborate spells cater to varying levels of experience and time commitment.
